definitions.definition: to press something, especially with your fingers

examples.text: to squeeze a tube of toothpaste
to squeeze the trigger of a gun *(= to fire it)*
He squeezed her hand and smiled at her.
Just take hold of the tube and squeeze.
‘I know,’ she said, squeezing his hand gently.
I squeezed the last bit of toothpaste out of the tube.
By squeezing the bulb you will be pumping air into the jar.
He slowly squeezed the trigger.
She squeezed on the reins and the cart came to a halt.

definitions.definition: to get liquid out of something by pressing or twisting it hard
definitions.sensetop: squeeze something out of/from somethingsqueeze something (out)squeeze something + adj.

examples.text: to squeeze the juice from a lemon
She felt as if every drop of emotion had been squeezed from her.
Squeeze the juice of half a lemon over each fish.
He took off his wet clothes and squeezed the water out.
freshly squeezed orange juice
Soak the cloth in warm water and then squeeze it dry.

definitions.definition: to force somebody/something/yourself into or through a small space
definitions.sensetop: squeeze somebody/something into, through, etc. somethingsqueeze into, through, etc. somethingsqueeze through, in, past, etc.

examples.text: We managed to squeeze six people into the car.
examples.contextForm: squeeze somebody/something into, through, etc. something

examples.text: It's a pretty town, squeezed between the mountains and the ocean.
We managed to squeeze a lot into a week *(= we did a lot of different things)*.
His legs were squeezed together.
to squeeze into a tight dress
Can we squeeze into that parking space?
to squeeze through a gap in the hedge
They were able to squeeze through a gap in the fence.
If you move forward a little, I can squeeze past.

definitions.definition: to succeed in doing something with difficulty or by a small amount

examples.text: The candidate squeezed through to the next round by just ten votes.
She managed to squeeze past her opponent and into the final after an epic match.

definitions.definition: to get something by putting pressure on somebody, threatening them, etc.

examples.text: He's squeezing me for £500.

definitions.definition: to strictly limit or reduce the amount of money that somebody/something has or can use

examples.text: High interest rates have squeezed the industry hard.

definitions.definition: to get as much money, information, etc. out of somebody as you can

wordOrigin: mid 16th cent.: from earlier squise, from obsolete queise, of unknown origin.
